item.title: Topic 2: Early Methods
item.description: Reading Francis Bacon, The New Organon (1620). Read Book 2, sections 10–16 (this starts on page 53 of the linked PDF), but skim through the examples to get a general sense of what’s going on with them, and focus on the beginning and end. Isaac Newton [Regulae Philosophandi][regulae] (Rules of Philosophy) as published in Philosophiæ Naturalis Principia Mathematica by Isaac Newton (1687, 1726) link forthcoming See also “Francis Bacon” in the SEP, by Jürgen Klein “A History of the Liver, Spleen, and Gallbladder” at The History of The Body Site (Stanford) Vesalius’s anatomical images in the Wellcome Collection (CC-BY)

item.title: Topic 1: Logic
item.description: What is logic? What is deductive logic? Could deductive logic be the logic of science? Is non-deductive logic possible? Reading (This is what you should read for this section. The due dates appear on the schedule.) Ian Hacking, An Introduction to Probability and Inductive Logic (purchased book) Chapter 1 “Logic”, whole chapter, pages 1–7. Robin Smith, “Aristotle’s Logic” in the Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy. Read the brief/unnumbered preface then sections 1, 2, 3, and 6.
